Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Virtual STEM Buddies for Personalized Learning Experiences in Free Choice Informal Learning Settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cyberlearning and Future Learning Technologies Program funds efforts that will help envision the next generation of learning technologies and advance what we know about how people learn in technology-rich environments. This project investigates how to provide customized instructional scaffolding to young kids to learn science in unstructured, out-of-school environments. The innovation is in using 'virtual STEM buddies' (VSBs), a computerized character that functions as both a mentor and a peer, and interacts with a child across exhibits within a children's museum to help them learn about Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics. Research will examine how to design and build such technologies, and how the 'virtual buddy' fits into other learning interactions (such as those between parent and child, or between museum guide and child).

The VSB, an intelligent embodied agent, will be built and pilot tested at the Children's Museum of Atlanta, with engineering research focusing on how to ensure the agent can align with the learner's knowledge and passions in what Crowley and Jacobs term 'islands of expertise'. Key features will include assessment of and alignment to the youth's prior knowledge; an interaction tailored to social construction of knowledge and continuity over time (so that the agent evolves with the child); and opportunistic instruction based on teachable moments both within and outside the museum. Engineering research will explore, in conjunction with participatory design, technologies for visitor identification (barcode, RFID, biometrics), user experience design to explore input methods in the noisy environment of a children's museum, and mechanisms to handle 'bottlenecking' of visitors (i.e., to allow an acceptable multi-user experience if multiple children want to access the VSB technology at an exhibit). The learning research will focus on discourse of youth in the museum with adults and peers, and will be augmented with a brief post exhibit attitudinal survey based on the "Changes in Attitudes about the Relevance of Science" instrument.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER project aimed to better understand how a Virtual Stem Buddy (VSB) can capture children's interest and scaffold learning in the Children's Museum of Atlanta (CMA) informal learning environment.  This project is a partnership of CMA, Dr. Kyle Johnsen and Dr. Grace Ahn at the University of Georgia, and Dr. Betsy DiSalvo at the Georgia Institute of Technology.  For CMA, the goal for this project was to see how technology such as a VSB could scaffold understanding from hands-on museum exhibitions, such as our giant ball machine that contains the six simple machines (lever, pulley, wheel and axle, inclined plane, screw and wedge.  The ball machine is one of the favorite museum exhibits, with a stay time of on average of 45 minutes, but little explicit STEM knowledge is gained from the experience. The VSB experience is designed to complete that knowledge, by showing, for example, through the game how a lever works. In order to reach this goal, the project included identifying potential technological challenges, including identifying users, appearance, customizing the VSB for each user, environmental interference, user input, museum bottlenecks, interacting with users, serving children with special needs, and evolving discussions over repeated visits and out-of-museum interactions.  

We accomplished several major activities as a part of this project. 

1) Dr. Betsy DiSalvo at Georgia Tech, conducted focus groups at the Museum with parents and children to guide the development and layout of the VSB environment.  Key learnings here included that children in the museum's age range preferred a non-human avatar as their guide and that their parents did not wish to receive more apps or other guidelines on how to better teach their children STEM concepts.  This information helped to guide the design of the system.

2) The VSB exhibition was successfully designed and installed at the museum and is still running. Data is collected on a daily basis.

We overcame the hurdles described above by the following actions.  Dr. Kyle Johnsen and his team at UGA were responsible for the programming portion of this project.  CMA designed the kiosk, installed it, conducted observations of the games and worked interactively with Dr. Johnsen and his team.  CMA has an ongoing responsibility of maintenance; Dr. Johnsen’s team oversees the technology and monitors usage.  We overcame the barriers mentioned above in the following ways:

  • First, we addressed the logistical hurdle of VSB configuration by integrating configuration into the kiosk, rather than having it be a separate app.
  • The avatar was designed to be created by the children, but not as a version of themselves, but rather a fanciful construct, that enabled them to be more playful in a children’s Museum environment.
  • We also shifted from wrist-bands to simple 5-digit alphanumeric codes. Parents enter their phone number to receive a text code for each of their children's VSBs. This is scalable to any number of kiosks. 
  • We implemented a first STEM mini game, updated it and then a second STEM mini-game that has enabled us to introduce additional STEM concepts such as force, velocity, and projectile motion. 
  • Finally, we implemented a more intuitive 3D interaction technique that enables parents and children to select and manipulate 3D objects more efficiently, and has led to significantly more frequent use of the exhibit.

 

Significant Results:  The kiosk has had over 10,000 interactions with children at the museum. The average length of each interaction is about 2-minutes for each game type. This is consistent with our goals for an engaging interaction. Children are also complete game objectives at a high rate (> 50% of games are played to completion).
